STEP 2 - EVIDENCE-BASED TREATMENT SELECTION: Now I'll select treatments based on current clinical guidelines. - First-line treatment per guidelines: Surgical removal of cholesteatoma via mastoidectomy, with possible nerve decompression. - Supporting evidence: Surgery is the definitive treatment for cholesteatoma to prevent further tissue destruction and address facial nerve impairment. - Patient-specific considerations: Adult patient with facial nerve weakness, emphasizing urgent surgical intervention; care to minimize nerve injury during surgery. - Contraindications or cautions: Delay in surgery risks permanent nerve damage and intracranial complications; caution with surgical risks in comorbidities.  STEP 3 - PHARMACOLOGICAL INTERVENTIONS: If medications are appropriate, I'll select based on efficacy and safety. - Primary medication choice: Corticosteroids (e.g., dexamethasone 10 mg IV or oral taper) to reduce edema and nerve inflammation. - Rationale for selection: Steroids may improve nerve conduction if administered early, although definitive treatment is surgical. - Expected timeline for improvement: Some reduction in nerve edema may be noted within days; functional recovery depends on extent of nerve damage. - Key side effects to monitor: Infection, hyperglycemia, mood changes. - Alternative medications if first-line fails: No specific medications; antibiotics if infection is present.  STEP 4 - NON-PHARMACOLOGICAL INTERVENTIONS: I'll include lifestyle and behavioral interventions that enhance outcomes. - Primary non-drug interventions: Avoid activities that increase intratemporal pressure, keep the ear dry, and protect from infection. - Patient education priorities: Importance of surgical intervention, symptoms of worsening, and details about nerve recovery. - Lifestyle modifications: Maintain ear hygiene, avoid water exposure, and manage stress to aid recovery. - Behavioral interventions: Use of facial exercises as prescribed, support for anxiety related to neurological deficits.  STEP 5 - MONITORING & FOLLOW-UP STRATEGY: I'll establish appropriate monitoring and follow-up care. - Follow-up timeline: Surgical outpatient follow-up within 1 week post-op; neurological assessment at 2-4 weeks. - Monitoring parameters: Facial nerve function, signs of infection, wound healing, and residual or recurrent cholesteatoma. - Red flag symptoms: Sudden worsening facial weakness, new or worsening headache, deterioration of hearing, or signs of intracranial involvement. - Treatment response assessment: Improvement in facial nerve function over weeks; imaging if needed to assess residual disease. STEP 7 - COORDINATION & REFERRALS: What additional care coordination is needed? - Specialist referrals needed: Otolaryngologist-head and neck surgeon urgently for surgical management; neurology consult if neurological deficits persist or worsen. - Other healthcare team members: Audiologist for hearing assessment and rehabilitation; physical therapy for facial nerve recovery support. - Community resources: Support groups for facial nerve palsy, patient education materials. - Insurance/cost considerations: Discuss surgical costs and post-op care; provide resources for assistance if needed.
